newsitem.title: CHINA: China looks to passion fruit as opium substitute.
newsitem.headline: China looks to passion fruit as opium substitute.

text.p: Chinese experts have found a tasty alternative to the opium poppy crops feeding the nation's growing heroin habit -- passion fruit, the Economic Information Daily said on Tuesday.

Commercial passion fruit cultivation should be promoted as an alternative to the opium poppies grown by remote hill tribes who currently rely on the illegal drug for economic survival, the newspaper quoted experts at a recent conference as saying.
Passion fruit was nutritious, easy to grow and commanded even higher returns than opium poppies, making it the most efficient way to eliminate planting of the drug, it said.

Some power groups on the other side of the border in the notorious "Golden Triangle" drug cultivation area of Burma, Laos and Thailand would welcome Chinese assistance in finding alternative crops, the newspaper said.
It made no direct reference to opium growing within China, a phenomenon that officials in the southwestern border province of Yunnan have long been eager to play down.

Earlier this year, Beijing launched a new campaign against a tide of illegal narcotics, vowing to crack down on addicts, traffickers and local authorities that allowed growers to tend their illegal crops.
Nearly 20 years of economic reforms have weakened the social controls that allowed China to wipe out drug abuse in the 1950s, paving the way for surging demand.
By the end of 1995, China had registered 520,000 illegal drug users in 1,600 towns and counties, state media has said.
